causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Modulates IMT transition temperature
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: the IMT transition temperature for h-BNC with p-dominated conductance downshifts from 10.5 K to 3K when the gate voltage is varied from 28 V to -40 V, while the IMT transition temperature of h-BNC with n-dominated conductance drops down to 9.5 K when the gate voltage is increased from 28 V to 40 V.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Changes FWHM of IMT peak

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Shifts IMT transition temperature

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Decreases FWHM of IMT peak

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Suppresses the metallic state
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: in h-BNC doping with either electrons or holes seems to suppress the metallic state, i.e., the range of temperatures in which the system is metallic decreases with doping.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Affects resistance via a common mechanism for metallic and insulating regimes

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Increases screening, decreases Ti

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: suppresses interlayer magnetic coupling and isolates the kagome planes

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: hole dopes the material

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: shifts kagome oxygen atoms almost completely into the kagome plane

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Holes doped only into the moiré layer, monolayer remains charge neutral

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: 2s exciton loses transition amplitude and sensitivity to correlated insulating states

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Holes doped into the monolayer
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At 𝐸 = -10 mV/nm, the spectra for 𝜈≤1 resemble that of Fig. 1e, f. For 𝜈 > 1, the 1s exciton turns into an attractive polaron (redshifted branch, denoted as X+) and a repulsive polaron (blueshifted branch, not labeled), which signal hole doping into the monolayer.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Holes shared between monolayer and moiré layer before density in moiré layer reaches νm = 1. Electron crystal states cannot be identified.
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: At larger electric fields (𝐸 = 15 and 18 mV/nm), the polaron feature (X+) appears at smaller 𝜈’s (< 1) in the reflection spectrum; accordingly, the extended region of 𝜈𝑚 = 1 emerges at larger 𝜈’s (> 1) in the PL spectrum. In addition, the electron crystal states can no longer be identified.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Holes in the monolayer screening extended Coulomb repulsion in the moiré layer
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Quantum melting of electron crystal states
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The electron crystal states are quantum melted because the extended Coulomb repulsion in the moiré layer that induces these states are screened by the holes in the monolayer.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Dipolar excitonic insulator at total filling ν = 1
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The state is consistent with the dipolar excitonic insulator induced by the strong interlayer Coulomb interaction: holes in the monolayer (𝜈𝑓) and in the moiré layer (𝜈𝑚) with 𝜈𝑚+ 𝜈𝑓 = 1 form effective dipolar excitons with exciton density 𝜈𝑋 = 𝜈𝑓.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Exciton density increases, exciton binding energy decreases, excitonic insulator weakens
causal_relationships.affected_property: Exciton density, binding energy, insulator strength
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The exciton density increases with electric field; the exciton binding energy decreases and the excitonic insulator weaken.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Excitons transition to electron-hole plasma
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The state can no longer be observed (e.g. at 𝐸≳ 30 mV/nm) beyond the exciton Mott density, at which the excitons turn into an electron-hole plasma.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: Strong interlayer Coulomb correlation in the excitonic insulating state

causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Finally, we demonstrate charge localization and emergence of local magnetic moments in the monolayer induced by the strong interlayer Coulomb correlation in the excitonic insulating state.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: increase in Tc and a decrease in TCDW

causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The robustness of the CDW ordering to the In substitution also suggests that the carrier concentration does not change sufficiently.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: formation of built-in electric fields in N-layer structures
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Due to the different electronegativity of S and Se these structures carry a finite out-of-plane dipole moment. As we show here by means of density functional theory (DFT) calculations, this intrinsic dipole leads to the formation of built-in electric fields when the monolayers are stacked to form N-layer structures. For sufficiently thin structures (N < 4) the dipoles add up and shift the vacuum level on the two sides of the film by ∼N · 0.7 eV. However, for thicker films charge transfer occurs between the outermost layers forming atomically thin n- and p-doped electron gasses at the two surfaces.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: dipoles add up
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: For sufficiently thin structures (N < 4) the dipoles add up and shift the vacuum level on the two sides of the film by ∼N · 0.7 eV.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: charge transfer between outermost layers
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: However, for thicker films charge transfer occurs between the outermost layers forming atomically thin n- and p-doped electron gasses at the two surfaces.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: tuning doping concentration
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The doping concentration can be tuned between about 5 · 10^12 e/cm^2 and 2 · 10^13 e/cm^2 by varying the film thickness.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: counteract static dipoles
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The surface charges counteract the static dipoles leading to saturation of the vacuum level shift at around 2.2 eV for N > 4.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: dissociates intralayer excitons into interlayer excitons
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: We show that the build-in electric field in structures with up to around 20 layers is sufficient to dissociate intralayer excitons into interlayer excitons, which is the critical step for achieving charge separation.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: electron doping
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: With the intercalation of Cu atoms, more electrons fill the bottom of conduction bands of ZrSe2, which change the electronic structure from semiconducting to metallic characters.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: n-type doping
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The donated electron from the Cu 4s shell can make a stable closed-shell Cu+ resulting in an increased charge distribution within ZrSe2 layers.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: reduced thermal conductivity
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: The introduction of random sulfur vacancies increases phonon scattering and limits their mean free path (MFP), as evident from the stronger reduction in κ with increasing ρs.

causal_relationships.cause_parameter: ordered strips of vacancies with ns = 2
causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: thermal conductivity matches that of pristine MoS2
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: for a specific spacing of the S-vacancy strips, the acoustic phonons in MoS2 remain largely unaffected, with reduced interaction with optical phonons. Consequently, phonon group velocities are only slightly affected, leading to a negligible reduction in thermal conductivity.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: localized defect modes occur at higher frequencies, realizing a phonon band gap that reduces scattering events between acoustic and optical phonons
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: When the vacancies are arranged with periodicity ns = 2 instead, localized defect modes occur at higher frequencies, essentially realizing a phonon band gap that reduces the scattering events between acoustic and optical phonons, since fewer states are available for scattering thus enhancing their MFP. Furthermore, Umklapp processes involving interactions between phonons of different branches are strongly suppressed, greatly reducing the system thermal resistance.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: thermal conductivity of the SL can exceed that of both constituent materials
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: in the limit of small periods, the thermal conductivity of the SL can exceed that of both the constituent materials, as a result of a dramatic reduction in the scattering of acoustic phonons by optical phonons, leading to very long phonon lifetimes.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Improved local structure around defects, reduced phonon influence
causal_relationships.affected_property: Increased T1 from 1.20±0.40 ms (5K) to 60.29±44.58 ms (room temperature), enabled room temperature coherent control with T2 = 20.89±9.59 µs
causal_relationships.mechanism_quote: Although the measurement methods are different, the extended T1 (tens of milliseconds) at room temperature can clearly show that long time annealing could be efficient way to relax the local structure around defects and reduce the influence from phonons.

causal_relationships.effect_on_doping: Suppression of ferromagnetism and transition to antiferromagnetic state
